qas.question: Was sound quality from disc to disc and between players consistent or varied?
Was analog or digital formatting more popular with enthusiasts?
What result did adding CX Noise Reduction have on analog discs?

answers.text: improved the signal-noise ratio of their audio

qas.question: Which company added digital sound option when re-releasing movies?

context: At least where the digital audio tracks were concerned, the sound quality was unsurpassed at the time compared to consumer videotape, but the quality of the analog soundtracks <a0_0>varied greatly<a0_0/> depending on the disc and, sometimes, the player. Many early and lower-end LD players had poor analog audio components, and many early discs had poorly mastered analog audio tracks, making <a1_0>digital<a1_0/> soundtracks in any form most desirable to serious enthusiasts. Early DiscoVision and LaserDisc titles lacked the digital audio option, but many of those movies received digital sound in later re-issues by <a3_0>Universal<a3_0/>, and the quality of analog audio tracks generally got far better as time went on. Many discs that had originally carried old analog stereo tracks received new Dolby Stereo and Dolby Surround tracks instead, often in addition to digital tracks, helping boost sound quality. Later analog discs also applied CX Noise Reduction, which <a2_0>improved the signal-noise ratio of their audio<a2_0/>.
